matched.actualTitle: Reflected XSS via Attribute Injection in 'name' Parameter
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same XSS vulnerability on the /xss10 endpoint. The expected finding describes an insufficient regex filter bypass, and the actual finding provides the specific technical mechanism (attribute injection via unencoded quote character). Both confirm HIGH severity XSS with arbitrary JavaScript execution capability. The actual finding demonstrates the vulnerability with working payloads like '" onmouseover="alert(1)', showing how the application's attempt to block basic script tags fails to prevent attribute-based XSS vectors.

extra.title: Server Version Information Disclosure in HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - not identified in expected findings. This is a legitimate information disclosure vulnerability where the application exposes Werkzeug/1.0.1 and Python/3.13.3 version information in the Server header, which aids attackers in reconnaissance and identifying known CVEs.

extra.title: HTTP Method Enumeration via 405 Method Not Allowed Response
extra.location: Root endpoint (/) and all endpoints responding to unsupported HTTP methods
extra.assessment: New discovery - not identified in expected findings. This is a legitimate information disclosure vulnerability where the application reveals supported HTTP methods through the Allow header in 405 responses, enabling attackers to enumerate API capabilities.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - not identified in expected findings. This is a legitimate configuration issue where critical security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-Content-Type-Options, X-XSS-Protection, Content-Security-Policy, Strict-Transport-Security) are missing from all HTTP responses, reducing defense-in-depth protections.

extra.title: Overly Permissive Cache-Control Headers on Static Assets
extra.assessment: New discovery - not identified in expected findings. This is a legitimate security configuration issue where static assets are served with 'Cache-Control: public, max-age=43200' (12-hour cache), creating risks for stale content delivery and potential security fix delays.
